abstractText: The present study encompasses the ethnomedicinal consumption of Corchorus depressus (L.) C.Chr. (C. depressus) for diabetes. Plant samples were subjected to LC-ESIMS analyses. The n-hexane, methanolic and water extracts were screened for -glucosidase inhibition and in vivo anti-diabetic studies. Further, antioxidant (DPPH) and antiinflammatory study was performed via luminol-enhanced chemiluminescence assay. The identified compounds were docked against the target enzymes of diabetes. The n-hexane fraction (CD-J1) showed IC50 of 8.4 ± 0.1 μg mL -1 against-glucosidase enzyme. The subfractions CD-12 and CD-13 of CD-J1 obtained after flash column chromatography displayed further reduced IC50 values of 4.3  0.1 and 6.3  0.1, respectively, as compared with standard drug acarbose (IC50 values of 37.5 ± 0.2 μg mL -1 ). Simultaneously, dereplication of the most active sub-fraction CD-12 by LC-ESI-MS led to the identification of strophanthidin and some other active metabolites responsible for anti-diabetic activity. Molecular docking of strophanthidin with -glucosidase and -amylase revealed high affinity for these target enzymes.

sections.text: depressus (L.) C.Chr. (C. depressus) for diabetes. Plant samples were subjected to LC-ESIMS analyses. The n-hexane, methanolic and water extracts were screened for -glucosidase inhibition and in vivo anti-diabetic studies. Further, antioxidant (DPPH) and antiinflammatory study was performed via luminol-enhanced chemiluminescence assay. The identified compounds were docked against the target enzymes of diabetes. The n-hexane fraction (CD-J1) showed IC50 of 8.4 ± 0.1 µg mL -1 against-glucosidase enzyme. The subfractions CD-12 and CD-13 of CD-J1 obtained after flash column chromatography displayed further reduced IC50 values of 4.3  0.1 and 6.3  0.1, respectively, as compared with standard drug acarbose (IC50 values of 37.5 ± 0.2 µg mL -1 ). Simultaneously, dereplication of the most active sub-fraction CD-12 by LC-ESI-MS led to the identification of strophanthidin and some other active metabolites responsible for anti-diabetic activity. Molecular docking of strophanthidin with -glucosidase and -amylase revealed high affinity for these target enzymes. Keywords: Corchorus depressus (L.) C.Chr.; LC-ESI-MS; Diabetes mellitus; -Glucosidase; Molecular docking

sections.heading: Chemicals and drugs
sections.text: α-Glucosidase from baker's yeast (E.C.3.2.1.20), acarbose, ascorbic acid, methanol, alloxan, p-nitrophenyl-α-D-glucopyranoside, sodium potassium tartarate, sodium carbonate, and glibenclamide were procured from Sigma-Aldrich, Merck, and Fluka. companies. The other commonly used chemicals, such as Tris-HCl buffer, Na2CO3, NaOH, HCl, Na2PO4, KH2PO4 and DMSO were of analytical grade. The LC-ESI-MS used in this study was Agilent 6460 series triple quadrupole. The other instruments used in this study include Epoch (BioTek, USA) 96-microplate reader, EZ-Fit Enzyme Kinetics software (Perrella Scientific Inc., Amherst, USA), vacuum pump, rotary evaporator (Buchi), glucometer (ACCU-Check, Germany), spectrophotometer (Shimadzo, Japan).

sections.heading: Plant collection and extraction
sections.text:
The whole plant (including roots) of C. depressus was collected from Chak Lehaar (Cholistan desert) in three different seasons dated 10 September 2018, 15 January 2018, 14 May 2018, and identified by Dr. M. Warris (Voucher No.3473/CIDS/IUB) a taxonomist at Cholistan Institute of Desert Studies, The Islamia University of Bahawalpur. Dried and powdered whole plant material (150 g) collected in different seasons (January, May and September) was macerated separately in 1.5 L of n-hexane at room temperature for 10 days. Extraction was repeated x 3 to get hexane extracts. The whole procedure resulted 03 extracts of hexane namely CD-J1 (January 2018), CD-M1 (May 2018), CD-S3 (September 2018) for three different seasons. Subsequently, similar procedure was repeated with 1.5 L of methanol to get methanol extracts namely CD-J4 (January 2018), CD-M5 (May 2018), CDS6 (September 2018) followed by maceration with double distilled water to get aqueous extracts namely CD-J7 (January 2018), CD-M8 (May 2018), CD-S9 (September 2018). For fractionation and chromatographic purposes, 7 kg dried plant powder (collected in January)
was soaked in 15 L hexane for 10 days. The whole protocol was done in triplicate and received 46 g crude hexane extract (Zohra, Ovais et al. 2019).

sections.heading: LC-ESI-MS Analyses
sections.text: LC-ESI-MS analyses were performed on Agilent 6460A triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (Singapore) coupled to Agilent infinity 1260 HPLC system (Singapore) fitted with a column thermostat and a binary pump. The chromatographic separation was performed on Agilent SB-C18 column (2.1 × 50 mm, 1.8 µm particle size). Ultra-pure water (A) and HPLC grade methanol (B) were used as mobile phase with 0.1% formic acid as additive in both solvents. A constant solvent flowrate of 0.4 mL/min was set and 5 µL of sample solutions were injected. Each run was completed in overall 11 min run-time. The linear mobile phase gradient was started with 10% B and maintained there for 2 min, then raised to 90% B and maintained for next 3 min, lowered back to 10% B in 0.5 min and again maintained for next 2.5 min. The plant's metabolites were confirmed by the LC-MS analysis. The retention time of all the metabolites were confirmed by the LC which are mentioned on the individual chromatograms separately. Moreover, the LC-ESI MS confirmed the secondary metabolites by comparing the ionization and fragmentation pattern of each metabolite with the standard sample data within the library of the instrument (Papp, Apati et al. 2004; Lacey, McMahon et al. 2008; Singh, Bajpai et al. 2021).

sections.heading: Bioassay guided fractionation
sections.text:
The hexane extract CD-J1 exhibited considerable inhibitory activity against α-glucosidase enzyme so it has been fractionated using increasing polarity of ethyl acetate in hexane and got 23 sub-fractions CD-1 to CD-23. These hexane fractions were assayed against αglucosidase inhibition and finally most active fraction CD-12 was subjected to LCMS for chemical profiling.
In vitro biological studies All extracts of C. depressus were subjected to following in vitro screenings.
α-Glucosidase inhibition study α-Glucosidase inhibition assay on C. depressus extracts was performed with method reported earlier (Chapdelaine, Tremblay et al. 1978). The IC50 values of active samples were calculated from the data using EZ-Fit Enzyme Kinetics Software (Perrella Scientific Inc., Amherst, USA) and compared it with standard, acarbose (IC50 37.5 ± 0.2 µg/mL / 65.7 ± 1.9 mM).

sections.heading: Antioxidant study
sections.text: Free radical scavenging activity of 1,1-diphenyl-2-picrylhydrazyl radical (DPPH) was measured as reported (Koleva, Van Beek et al. 2002). Quercetin and L-ascorbic acid were used as standards. Percent scavenging activity was calculated by the following formula. Percent scavenging activity = [100 - (Abs of test compound/Abs of control)] x 100

sections.heading: Anti-inflammatory study
sections.text:
Anti-inflammatory activity was measured using luminol-enhanced chemiluminescence assay following previously reported protocol (Helfand, Werkmeister et al. 1982).
In vivo anti-diabetic activity The 2 kg dried C. depressus was extracted with 8 X 3 L of methanol for a week, filtered and solvent was evaporated by rotary evaporation to obtain 81 g of crude extract. In vivo antidiabetic activity was evaluated on albino Sprague-Dawley rats (either sex), weighing about 200-250 g. The experimental protocol was the same as reported earlier by our research group (Hayat, Sarwar et al. 2014).

sections.heading: Induction of diabetes mellitus
sections.text:
Alloxan monohydrate (150 mg/ kg) was used to induce diabetes mellitus (DM) in rats. The alloxan was injected twice 75 mg/kg on first day and on third day of the first dose. As
reported previously, the alloxan was dissolved in citrate buffer (pH 4.5) to inject intraperitoneally to the 18 hours fasted rats (Hayat, Sarwar et al. 2014). The alloxan dose was optimized through earlier trials (data not shown). Subsequently experimental rats were given a 20% dextrose solution after four hours of alloxan injection to avoid alloxan induced hypoglycemia in rats due to excessive discharge of insulin from necrotic pancreas (Mohammed, Kakey et al. 2020). All experimental rats were maintained on 5% glucose in drinking water (Kumar, Nandakumar et al. 2011) for next 24 hours. Glucometer was used to monitor glucose levels. All the animals with ≥ 200 mg/dL blood glucose levels were selected for the evaluation of anti-diabetic effect of crude C. depressus extracts (Ahmad, Ullah et al. 2020).
Animals grouping and drug administration The on-set of diabetes mellitus DM was noted from the fifth day of initial dose of alloxan. Animals were acclimatized in this condition around one week. Fasting blood glucose levels were tested on 7 th day after dividing animals into different groups. As per literature, the DM management was commenced at the same day by considering it the 0 day of the study. Sequel determination of fasting blood glucose levels was carried out on 0, 1 st and 4 th days (ElDemerdash, Yousef et al. 2005; Kumar, Nandakumar et al. 2011). Following treatment procedure was employed: Group A: Normal Control (citrate buffer 4 mL/kg, i.p.) Group B: Positive Control (normal saline 4 mL/kg + alloxan 150 mg/kg, i.p.) Group C: Standard Control (glibenclamide 10 mg/kg + alloxan 150 mg/kg, i.p.) Group D: C. depressus 50 mg/kg + alloxan 150 mg/kg, i.p.) Group E: C. depressus 75 mg/kg + alloxan 150 mg/kg, i.p.) Group F: C. depressus 100 mg/kg + alloxan 150 mg/kg, i.p.)

sections.heading: Analysis
sections.text:
A drop of fasting blood glucose was obtained from the pricked tip of experimental animal
tail, and the blood glucose levels were measured using glucometer in the range 10 to 600 mg/dL.

sections.heading: Molecular docking studies
sections.text:
To get insight into the binding mechanism of the compound strophanthidin, molecular docking simulation was performed using α-amylase and yeast α-glucosidase. The crystal structure of the yeast α-glucosidase has not been reported yet. Therefore, homology modeling was performed using isomaltase from S. cerevisiae (PDB ID: 3A4A) as a template (Yamamoto, Miyake et al. 2010), using the protocol mentioned in the (Barakat, Ali et al. 2017). While, the crystal structure of alpha α-amylase (PDB ID: 1B2Y) was retrieved from protein data bank. Water molecules were removed, and both proteins were prepared and protonated by using structure preparation module available in MOE. The compound was build using the builder module of MOE 2018.0101 (Molecular Operating Environment (MOE), 2013.08; Chemical Computing Group ULC, 1010 Sherbooke St. West, Suite #910, Montreal, QC, Canada, H3A 2R7, 2018. 2018). Further compound was charged and minimized by using MMFF94x force field (Halgren 1996). For docking simulation default parameters were used. Thirty conformations were generated and saved in mdb format (Ghufran, Rehman et al. 2020).

sections.heading: Footnote:
sections.text:
Values are expressed as Mean ± SEM and n = 5. Student’s t test was used for analysis. P values are considered as P < 0.05 = significant (*), P < 0.01 = more significant (**) and P < 0.001 = highly significant (***) when compared with positive control. P < 0.001 = highly significant ( ### ), when compared with normal control. All extracts treated groups and standard controls were compared with positive control and positive control was compared with normal control.

title: LC-ESI-MS analysis, antioxidant, anti-diabetic and molecular docking studies on Corchorus depressus (L.) C.Chr
